A standard comprehensive policy pays out the IDV, which is the vehicle’s value after depreciation.

An RTI add-on ensures that the claim payout is the full invoice value of the car, covering costs like registration fees and road tax, which a standard policy does not.

For example, if you bought a car for 8 lakh (including taxes) and it is declared a total loss, a standard policy would pay the depreciated IDV, but RTI would pay the original 8 lakh.

Your parents can help you save money 

If you work from home and stay with your parents/relatives then you won’t be able to claim your HRA exemption and the whole amount you receive will be taxable.

That’s when you can pay rent to your parents and show it to your employer and claim HRA exemption.

Here’s how it is calculated.

Let’s consider a situation where,

1. Annual Basic salary: 3.6 LPA (30k/month)
2. Annual rent: 1.8 Lakh
3. HRA received: 1.8 Lakh

Now the lowest amount among the below 3 conditions will be exempted from Tax.

1. 50% basic salary + DA = 1.8L

2. Rent - (10% of Basic + DA) = 1.44L

3. HRA received= 1.8 L

So the lowest amount among the 3 is 1.44 lakh, which means out of 1.8 lakh HRA you receive, you will only have to pay tax for 36k.

But what if you hadn’t paid rent, then the whole 1.8L would be taxable.

Please note a few important things.

1. You will have to make a proper house agreement with your parents/relatives.

2. You should actually transfer money on a regular basis.

3. The rental amount they receive, only 70% of it will be taxable.

4. This is only applicable if you choose old tax regime.

This is called loan restructuring.

This was introduced in a situation where borrowers like us are not able to cope up with the high interest rate of the bank loans due to several situations like health issues, job loss etc.

So you can ask your banks for loan restructuring, this may not be the best option but it is much better than not paying your EMIs or defaulting the loan as it can affect your credit score drastically.

In fact, even banks don’t want you to default the loan or not pay the EMIs, hence they will also be generous enough to help you in restructuring your loan.

Talking about restructuring, it could happen in multiple ways.

Either you can increase the loan tenure (No. Of years), due to which the monthly EMI amount will reduce.

Or you can ask for the moratorium of the EMI payments, which means you might get a few months break from paying your EMIs. But please note, here the interest amount will continue to add up, just that you don’t have to pay EMIs for a few months.

Or you could convert your personal loan which is an unsecured loan to secured loan by giving collateral to banks such as gold, house, car etc. due to which the interest rate will slightly decrease because banks love secured loans as there is high amount of trust and very low chance of defaulting the loan.

If you are going through a hard time, you can request your bank manager for loan restructuring and they will definitely help you out.

Before we jump into the conclusion let me explain to you that there are 2 types of loan, secured loan and unsecured loan.

Secured loan means, we have to give some sort of collateral to the banks to get loans from them.

Unsecured loans mean, we don’t have to give any sort of collateral to get loans from the banks.

And banks love secured loan than anything else. That’s why the approval time & the interest rates are much lower compared to unsecured loans.

So whenever you are taking a loan, please go for a secured loan instead of an unsecured loan, because having a secured loan will mean that you are a trust worthy borrower & in turn your credit score will improve.

So there’s this unsaid rule that, if you keep the ratio of secured loan to unsecured loan in 80 to 20 ratio, your credit score will generally improve.

Note: Examples of secured loans are, gold loan, home loan etc.

Examples of unsecured loans are, personal loan, student loan, credit card loan etc.

In simple words, we all know that the value of the car decreases with time right. For eg, I bought an eco sport 9 years ago for 11 lakhs now it’s worth Max to max 4 to 5 lakhs.

Why is that? It is because of depreciation.

Due to general wear and tear happening with the car, the value of each parts falls, due to which the value of whole cars go down.

Generally, after 5 years of buying the car, it’s value decreases by 50%.

Let’s assume you bought a car for 10 lakhs 5 years ago, now it’s worth 5 lakhs.

But if you had bought depreciation cover as an add on by only paying 15% more premium, you would have got total 10 lakhs from the insurance company.

Car depreciation is the difference in the value of the car between the time it was purchased & when it was sold.

Every car depreciates with time due to natural wear and tear.

This is the average depreciation rate.

0 - 6 months: 5%
6 months - 1 year: 15%
1 year - 2 years: 20%
2 years - 3 years: 30%
3 years - 4 years: 40%
4 years to 5 years: 50%

Above 5 years: Mutually decided between the insurer & vehicle owner.

So after speaking to a car reseller, they told me that it is better to buy a car which is somewhere around 5 years old and sell it within 2 years. 

By this, there won’t be any significant depreciation and you get somewhat the same price as what you bought.

Always check whether your health insurance has a room rent limit or not. It’s always suggested to get an insurance without any such limit because there is something called as ‘PROPORTIONATE DEDUCTION’ 

For eg, if your insurance is of ₹3 lakh & the room rent limit will be 0.1% of 3,00,000 ie. ₹3,000.

Assume your bill is ₹90,000

If you are admitted in a hospital room which has a rent of ₹9,000, then the insurance won’t pay your complete bill because you used 3 times the room rent limit.

Now, insurance company will deduct
1. Cost of pharmacy 
2. Cost of implant & medical device
3. Cost of diagnostics

From that ₹90,000 & divide the remaining amount by 3, because you spent 3 times the room rent limit.

I know it’s a lot of head ache, so please choose an insurance without any room rent limit.

EPF or Employee’s Provident Fund is a government-approved retirement benefits scheme available to eligible salaried individuals employed in India.

Employer’s Provident Fund Organization (EPFO) allows employees to partially withdraw money from their PF accounts and use it as a personal loan to deal with emergency situations. While this is often referred to as an EPF Loan it is not exactly a loan but actually an advance as the amount withdrawn does not have to be paid back (non-refundable) in most cases (unlike in case of a personal loan).

It can be used for marriage, education, purchase of home, medical treatment, home loan payment etc.

Difference between flat interest rate & Reducing Interest rate.

Let’s say you take a loan for ₹5,00,000 at 10% interest for 10 years.

- With Flat Interest Rate

Monthly EMI - ₹8,333
Total interest - ₹5,00,000
Total Amount - ₹10,00,000

- Reducing Interest Rate

Monthly EMI - ₹6,608
Total interest - ₹2,92,904
Total Amount - ₹7,92,904

You will save ₹2,07,096 with reducing balance interest rate.

Flat interest rate means, the interest rate will be same throughout the year & it will be calculated on the principal amount ie, ₹5,00,000

Reducing balance interest rate means the interest will be calculated in the outstanding amount of the loan, which keeps decreasing as you repay your EMI.

️ India’s real estate boom is pricing Indians out of homes.
What we’re building today isn’t housing — it’s speculation.

Let me explain:

1️⃣ Mumbai
– Flats in Worli & Bandra now sell for ₹80,000–₹2.5 lakh per sq. ft.
– But most remain vacant.
– Owned by investors who never live there.
– Supply exists, but it’s locked away from real people.

2️⃣ Gurgaon
– Super-luxury towers like DLF Camellias are selling at ₹100 Cr+.
– These are 2nd, 3rd, even 4th homes.
– Local incomes can’t keep up = locals pushed out.
– Empty towers dominate the skyline.

3️⃣ Hyderabad
– Was once affordable. But FOMO & easy credit inflated prices.
– Builders overbuilt. Demand collapsed.
– Resale prices dropped 15–30% in parts.
– Govt had to freeze new permissions.

Across metros, the pattern is the same:
 High prices, low occupancy, distorted demand.

But here’s the twist…

 Monaco — one of the richest places in the world — doesn’t allow this nonsense.

✅ You need to live in your house at least 6 months/year.
✅ Utilities & taxes are tracked to prevent idle assets.
✅ No proof of residency = no ownership.
✅ Wealth is filtered via deposits in Monaco banks.

Result?
– No ghost towers.
– No speculative frenzy.
– Locals aren’t priced out of their own city.

 Policy India needs (inspired by Monaco & others):
	1.	Vacancy Tax – Tax unused homes after 12 months.
	2.	Occupancy Declaration – Yearly audit of home use.
	3.	Higher Stamp Duty for Investors – Like in Hong Kong.
	4.	Builder Licensing Caps – Stop approvals in oversupplied markets.
	5.	Minimum Holding Periods – Higher tax if you flip in <3 years.

️ India’s goal should be to build homes, not hollow assets.
Otherwise, we’ll keep creating wealth traps, not wealth creators.

Delboeuf Illusion is generally a illusion created by our mind & restaurants use this to trick us to eat less and feel more full.

Assume there are 2 plates, one is larger & other is smaller one, now let’s also assume that there is same amount of food on both the plates.

Still we will feel that smaller plate has more food than the larger one. It is because we tend to decide the amount of food by the distance from the edge of the plate to the food, lesser it is, more food we assume.

So Restaurants generally decrease the plate & spoon size to make us feel that they have served more food than we needed.

It is generally seen in restaurants with unlimited buffet model.
